_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Springdale Ice Cream and Beverage
Ammonia PSM System
Executive Summary

Springdale Ice Cream and Beverage is a Kroger Company operated facility that manufactures ice cream and beverages, using an Ammonia (CAS# 7664-41-7) Refrigeration system to provide cooling and freezing capabilities. Since ammonia releases from the system, it could pose a risk of offsite impact. The system is regulated under OSHA PSM standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and is subjected to Program 3 requirements of the EPA?s Risk Management system.

The overriding purpose of the Ammonia PSM System is to prevent the unintended release of Ammonia from the refrigeration system as well as prevent fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic events. 

The PSM system covers in written format the following elements.

-Employee Participation
-Process Safety Information
-Process Technology
-Operating Procedures
-Non-Routine Work Practices
-Contractor Requirements
-Process Safety Review
-Mechanical Integrity
-Training Requirements
-Management of Change
-Pre-Startup Safety Review
-Incident Investigation
-Emergency Planning and Response
-Compliance Audits
-Security Against Theft

There have been no ammonia-related incidents at the Springdale Dairy within the last five years that have resulted in onside or offsite impacts.

Employee Participation:

The Engine Room technicians are in charge of the administration as well as actual operation of the system and maintain PSM files that are open to all employees. In addition to being run by the technicians involved in it?s operation, the other people in the plant are kept informed of PSM System status but initial training upon hire and periodic refresher training in safety meetings and plant wide events

Process Safety Information:

Written information has been collected which enables the employees to identify and understand the potential hazards in the system. The written information includes the ammonia MSDS and a description of the design of the ammonia refrigeration

system. An Emergency Response Summary book has been prepared and distributed to the Springdale and Sharonville Fire Department to help them to be prepared for an emergency response.

Process Hazard Analysis:

Formal studies using the What-If/Checklist Technique have been conducted to examine the system and identify potential hazards. This analysis has indicated shortcomings in the system, which has been corrected.

Operator Procedures:

Written, detailed procedures have been developed which describe the steps, which should be followed to safely operate the ammonia refrigeration system. These procedures are regularly audited for completeness and followed by all operators.

Training:

A training program has been developed which ensures that employees are trained in all aspects of the system and the duties, which they must perform in its operation. The program includes classroom, on-the-job and performance demonstrations elements.

Contractors:

All contractors working on the system are screened and evaluated by the operating technicians in charge of the PSM system before being allowed to work on the Ammonia Refrigeration System. Their work is constantly monitored by these same operators and they have complete authority to suspend the work if it is not been done properly.

Pre-Startup Safety Review

A pre-startup safety review is required for all new ammonia projects to verify that all safety programs are operational, training has been preformed, and that construction has been completed to design standards. This same review is also conducted when there is a change in the process safety information.

Mechanical Integrity:

This element of the system ensures that the ammonia refrigeration system is built and maintained using preventive and predictive maintenance procedures to minimize unexpected breakdown or failures.

Hot Work Permit:

This element of the system ensures that a signed permit is obtained before any cutting, welding, or open flame is used. This same syste

m is in place throughout the facility.

Management of Change:

These procedures are designed to insure that all changes made to the Ammonia Refrigeration system are properly designed and reviewed before implementing and that other elements of the PSM system are updated to reflect any changes.

Incident Investigation:

This element insures that any incidents (and `near misses?) are investigated and documented by an investigation team. Any recommendations are resolved immediately to improve the safety of the facility and personnel.

Compliance Audits:

There are procedures to conduct regular audits of the PSM system both by internal and external experts. Any recommendations by these audits are resolved.

System Security:

A system has been implemented to prevent theft or tampering with the system, including perimeter guarding, physical and electronic locks on critical equipment, and around clock monitoring by operators and Security Personnel.

All records of the PSM system are maintained in he PSM office located in the Engine Room of the facility, where they are open to examination at any time by concerned employees or management.
